ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot about monopolies and strategic competition between firms.
All we did was take derivatives over and over again for different economic models.
A basic understanding of models in industrial organisation.
Definitely learned a lot of the economics of competition, in may different topic areas.

I learned a lot about different competitive models, including various oligopoly models (Cournot, Bertrand, Stackelberg), with numerous addendums that makes it more applicable to real-life, including vertical & horizontal mergers along with strategic investment in cost-reducing technology. I also learned about how firms can exercise more market power with various pricing tools such as two-part tariffs.
I learned different models in the field of industrial organization, including but not limited to: different forms of competition, differentiation, adverse selection, strategic investment, etc.
About ECON models and the market competition.
Very good
I loved the gane theory portions of class.
I learned about a lot of game theory that firms undergo in different settingsmergers, monopolies/duopolies, and so forth.

THIS IS AN ECON THEORY CLASS. Industrial organization class. I've heard others describe it as the next step after intermediate micro (ECON 122), and that's pretty accurate. Learned about monopoly, price discrimination, durable goods, oligopoly, product differentiation, strategic investment, mergers, information, and auctions. Note, this is a class that is about using economic theory to model the behavior of firms and competition in markets.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Cover a lot of material, will learn a lot
Weaknesses: Course moves super fast. Professor Haile is literally also extremely anti question. He will make you feel like any question you ask is the dumbest thing ever to the point where no one asks a question.
Prof Haile does a decent job explaining things but sometimes goes too quickly. All the lectures are very fast paced.

The material is quite difficult but Prof. Haile tries his best to explain things as clearly as possible. I think this class would benefit from a discussion section seeing as the problem sets can be quite involved and much more advanced than material discussed in lecture.
Lectures were detailed. Professor Haile was fairly engaging. Material was very interesting given my interest in competition and anti trust policy.
Interesting models. The pace of the class was quite variable (really sped up towards the end), and outside help was limited, but overall interesting content.

Strengths: lectures notes are very clear and tailor-made for studying; this makes periods like reading week a lot less stressful. Material is challenging but fair; a lot of the PSETs stem from the lectures and the exams stem from the PSETs so there are no unpleasant surprises for the most part. Class is consistently engaging; Professor Haile is able to keep your attention and engagement despite it being a 9 AM.

The course is extremely organized and well-run. The professor is always well-prepared, and the TF was well equipped to answer questions. I enjoyed the class and don't think there is much room for improvement. Maybe 2 instead of 1 midterms would have broken up the material a bit more?
Logical linkage of course concepts and models.
Very strong
Very well paced course. Gets hard at times but nothing impossible.
Professor Haile is a great lecturer who really knows his stuff. The problem sets were fair and helped with learning the material. The exams were also quite fair. No glaring weaknesses to be honest.

Honestly, no weaknesses. Strengths: Professor Haile is one of the best lecturers in the economics department. You'll see this in his reviews in previous years, and it is 100% accurate. He is incredibly clear in his explanations, and his exams/problems sets are very fair. He's not the type to teach you material and then test you on something completely different. Rather, he teaches the material and tests you on what he teaches. That being said, the class is not an easy class. While Professor Haile is amazing at lecturing and communicating the ideas very clearly, the concepts are difficult and will take a little time to master.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would as I learned a lot, but keep in mind this is a challenging course. The workload isnt very high, but the material is challenging and professor haile will SPEED through it so you will have to go back and review a lot of the concepts.
No, do not take it. It seemed like Intermediate Micro all over again with just different concepts, yet more difficult.
Only if you're really interested in industrial organisation.

Absolutely. Any student interested in competition and anti trust policy should definitely take this course to gain a strong theoretical background in the field. As a side note, however, this is not an applied course-- we did not do work with data.

Yes, if you are looking for a senior seminar this is a great one to take. Challenging but not frustratingly so and it builds off of what you have learned throughout the rest of the Economics major - a good way to cap off what you initially learned.

Yes, especially if you are interested in game theory/micro-related topics. It's a great and well-organized class. Prof. Haile is a pretty interesting lecturer as well, so it's a very well-rounded advanced seminar.
Yes. Very insightful and rich knowledge in ECON market.
Yes
I would its a great senior seminar option.
Absolutely. One of the best 400-level Econ classes that you can take. Not too high of workload while learning about really interesting microeconomic dynamics. Please take!

Yes! If you are interested in economic theory, industrial organization (imperfect competition, etc.), then yes. It's a great class with a great professor (if Prof. Haile is teaching it). There's a lot of interesting topics, and if you enjoyed intermediate micro, then this would probably be a good class. It takes some of the assumptions we make (e.g. perfect competition) in intermediate micro and then relaxes those assumptions to see what happens in markets. It's pretty math-y and challenging. If you hated doing the algebra of the intermediate econ classes, you'll probably not like this class. 

If you're not super interested in econ theory or if you want to go into investing/finance/consulting, etc. you might find that this isn't exactly what you're looking forit's about basic economic models to understand things like oligopoly or product differentiation, but if you come into this class thinking you'll leave with a ton that will help you in your M&A investment banking job at Goldman or in your consulting job at Bain, I don't think you'll be very happy. That being said, if you're interested in learning about economic models to understand anti-trust policy, pricing discrimination, and competition in markets, then it'd be a great class for you!

Ultimately, I'd say that you should read the syllabus and know what you're signing up for. If you're looking for a good econ theory class, this is by far one of the best undergrad classes at Yale. If you're looking for an easy, low work-load senior seminar for your senior spring, you should probably pick something else.
